titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the David Ewing papers, 1809-1814.
titlestmt.author: Processed by: Rubenstein Staff; EAD finding aid derived from MARC record using marc2ead_sectionA.xsl

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid derived from MARC record via marc2ead_sectionA.xsl, May 2019

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University

did.abstract: Includes five letters from David Ewing in S.C. to his brother Maskell Ewing, an attorney in Philadelphia, chiefly concerning money matters; and one letter from M.C. Ewing concerning the incarceration of Maskell's brother and her need for financial assistance from the family to obtain his release. In one letter, David Ewing wrote that he was president of the Librarian Society of Savannah River, S.C.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.p: David Ewing Papers, 1809-1814. , David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.p: This finding aid was derived from a MARC record using a crosswalk defined in marc2ead_sectionA.xsl. The finding aid was generated as part of a larger project to digitize several thousand small collections housed in Section A, May 2019.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: David Ewing was a planter, from Mathews Bluff, S.C.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Includes five letters from David Ewing in S.C. to his brother Maskell Ewing, an attorney in Philadelphia, chiefly concerning money matters; and one letter from M.C. Ewing concerning the incarceration of Maskell's brother and her need for financial assistance from the family to obtain his release. In one letter, David Ewing wrote that he was president of the Librarian Society of Savannah River, S.C.
